Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Infusion of Geospatial Informatics to Enhance an Undergraduate Biological Science Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. This project seeks to infuse the undergraduate biology curriculum at Texas Southern University with geospatial informational science and technology (GIST). This will help prepare students to address global challenges in the fields of geospatial information, ecology, environmental science, and natural resource management. The activities and strategies are evidence-based and formative and summative evaluation are an integral part of the project.

This project has the objectives to 1) promote student interest in geospatial informatics thereby addressing the global need for an increasingly diversified geospatial workforce, 2) foster critical thinking and enhance problem solving skills to better prepare students for future careers demanding geospatial skills in a range of fields, 3) equip students with cutting edge geospatial technology skills to collect field data, create and interpret geospatial maps, and 4) increase the number of underrepresented students applying for graduate programs and internships in geospatial-related STEM-fields. This will be accomplished by adding geospatial content to modules in existing courses, creating a GIST-focused course, developing a new undergraduate certificate in geospatial science, and implementing a GIST undergraduate research program. Through a range of planned dissemination activities, this project has the potential to affect the implementation of GIST components at a range of institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geospatial Informatics is a rapidly expanding interdisciplinary science and is projected to be one of the nation's largest growth industries by US Bureau of Labor Statistics. In this program, undergraduate students were introduced to interdisciplinary teaching and research to meet 21st century global challenges in the fields of geospatial information, ecology, environmental science, and natural resource management. The specific objectives of the project were to: 1) infuse geospatial science concepts within the existing undergraduate curriculum, 2) establish and enhance undergraduate research opportunities in applied Geospatial Science, and 3) promote geospatial informatics awareness within the COSET and at the university. A total of 17 undergraduate students, participated in an intensive ten-week summer internship called Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE) over the project period, where the students were trained on different research techniques in remote sensing, GIS, microbiology and cell toxicology. A geospatial certificate program and courses in geospatial sciences were created in TSU. Also a total of 9 graduate students were supported and trained through this project. All the research projects fall under the broad umbrella of Urban Watersheds.

 

The rapid land use and land cover changes due to intense urbanization has a significant effect on ecology, environment, and human health in most of the urban watersheds. The Greens Bayou, Buffalo Bayou, Halls Bayou, Hunting Bayou and White Oak Bayou are the major bayous that drain into the Houston Ship Channel (HSC). The recent increase in frequency and intensity of the urban flooding events and repeated inundation of the neighborhoods along the Bayou makes it important to monitor the water and soil chemical characteristics in this region. The research objectives of the project are to 1) Monitor the historical water quality data of Houston Bayous, 2) to collect and analyze the nutrient and heavy metal concentrations in the water and soil samples along the bayous and 3) Analyze the bacterial contamination and cytotoxicity in the water and soil samples. Water and soil samples were collected and analyzed for the nutrient and metal concentrations from Buffalo, Brays, Greens, White Oak, Hunting, Halls, Mustang and Dickinson Bayou watersheds. Our results show that the N concentrations in all the bayous exceeded the Texas Human Health (THH) criteria of 10 ppm concentration in water samples. The P concentrations in all the sampling locations were well above the recommended maximum level of 0.1 ppm which is the proposed critical limit of EPA for algal bloom occurrence in surface water. The satellite image analysis of the Greens, Buffalo, Brays, Hunting, Halls, White Oak, Mustang and Dickinson bayou watershed shows that the vegetation cover decreased and the impervious surface cover increased during the period of 1984 to 2019. In case of Greens Bayou Watershed, the impervious surface area in the watershed increased by 62.2 % from 1984 to 2018 while the vegetative cover decreased by 30.6 % over the same period.

 

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this project is the development of comprehensive understanding of the nutrient, heavy metal, bacterial loading and distribution in watersheds and their impact on human gut cell viability. The project diversified the course curriculum by enhancing existing courses, establishing new undergraduate courses, and increasing the summer undergraduate research and training opportunities at TSU.  More specifically, the project: 1) promoted student interest in geospatial informatics, 2) improved critical thinking and enhance problem solving skills to better prepare students for future careers demanding geospatial skills in ecology, natural resources management, and environmental and health science, 3) equipped students with cutting-edge geospatial technology skills to collect field data, create and interpret geospatial maps, and 4) increased the number of minority students applying for graduate programs and internships in geospatial-related STEM-fields.

 

Broader Impacts: The project impacted the broader society through education, training and hands-on research experience for undergraduate and graduate students from Texas Southern University, so that more under-represented minorities can successfully enter the fields of environmental and interdisciplinary sciences. A total of 17 undergraduate students, successfully completed the intensive ten-week summer internship program at TSU, where the students were exposed to different research techniques in remote sensing, GIS, environmental sampling and analysis, microbial analysis and cytotoxicity. A total of 9 graduate students (3 MS and 6 PhD) developed thesis and dissertations and graduated Environmental Toxicology from TSU during the course of this project, Five more graduate students are working on their research project and are about to graduate. This project helped the students to gain training and experience in solving environmental problems and in preparing them for professional careers in industry, government and non-profit organizations. The project also uniquely impacted the undergraduate students to consider the research in environmental sciences and to pursue the M.S. and Ph.D. programs in their areas of interest and will enable to increase the enrollment of graduate students majoring in the STEM field of studies here at TSU.
